media_attachments.description: r/TwoHotTakes u/Puzzled_Ninja4085. 12h My Husband Says I'm Enmeshed Listener Write In I, 26 female, and husband, 25 male have been married for one year. We bought a house less than a year ago and everything has been great. We met during COVID and that really sped our relationship along. We dated and were married in 2 years. Before we started dating, I would hang out with my sister, 24 female,pretty much everyday. I would text or call her and my mom most days. After about 6 months of dating, my husband brought to my attention that we spend most of our time with my family. I saw his point and did my best to include his family in our free time. As we went on, he started to make comments about how I didn't need to call my mom everyday or how I'm in constant contact with my mom and sister. They are my best friends and I didn't find that weird. I did cut back to calling my mom once a week and not spending all evening texting my sister. My sister was single too, so we were so close. I think t

was going fine until he would start looking at my calls and texts. Then he would say, "You called your mom twice this week." And usually it was for something important, so I didn't see an issue. But to him this was me "breaking boundaries." In the years we've been together, he constantly goes through my phone and gets so upset when he sees texts or calls to my family, if I bring up a story about them, etc. He thinks my whole world revolves around them. When I don't really talk to them except for a couple snapchats, texts, and a phone call a week. Now a year-ish later and we are in our new house, we are constantly fighting about this. So much so, that he will sleep in a different room. My sister is getting married and he threw a fit when I went to the bachelorette party, the bridal showers, and even the rehearsal dinner. I want to be there for her, she means so much to me. I want to spend time with my parents, because they won't be here for forever & I don't want to have regrets when th

content:
Trapping AI: A Guide to Implementing a Structured Poisoning Mechanism in Static Websites

This guide provides a detailed examination of the implementation of a structured poisoning mechanism within static websites hosted on GitHub Pages and generated using Hugo.

The approach employs Markov-chain-based Quixotic to feed deceptive content to persistent bots and aggressive ‚ÄúAI‚Äù scrapers that circumvent robots.txt directives.

This implementation follows the methodological framework outlined by @gedankenstuecke, available at: https://tzovar.as/algorithmic-sabotage-ssg/.

For further details, visit: https://algorithmic-sabotage.github.io/asrg/trapping-ai/.

account.note: The Algorithmic Sabotage Research Group (ASRG) is an ongoing, conspiratorial, aesthetico-political, practice-led research framework focused on the intersection of digital culture and information technology.

fields.name: WEBSITE
fields.value: https://algorithmic-sabotage.github.io/asrg/about/

I‚Äôd appreciate some feedback on if this is useful/how it could be improved. If you‚Äôre running any type of website in 2025, you‚Äôll likely be suffering from the impact of...

content:
when it comes to people completely failing at all things #legal, I‚Äôm never surprised ‚Äì just constantly disappointed‚Ä¶

these folks are an Australian company using a text messaging contact widget delivered by a US company, using boilerplate disclaimers required by a US law (TCPA) that isn‚Äôt applicable in Australia, linking to T&Cs that are applicable to the US, with (of course üôÑ) US spelling of their crappy boilerplate

it‚Äôs clowns all the way down, I‚Äôm afraid ü§™ü§™ü§™

(and don‚Äôt even get me started on their provider‚Äôs use of ‚ÄúAI‚Äù bullshit in their contact widget ‚Äì even their T&Cs make it clear that it‚Äôs prone to hallucination & it‚Äôs on their customers‚Äô if that causes them problems ü§£üòÇü§£ )
 
 
 
^ noting, of course, that #IANAL | #IANYL - https://infosec.exchange/@itgrrl/112981771774149383 üíÅ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

media_attachments.description:
A redacted screenshot of a website text message contact widget thingy with red outlines & highlighting showing that:

- their physical address is in Australia 
- their website uses a .com.au domain 
- their ‚Äúlegal‚Äù boilerplate includes the phrase ‚ÄúConsent is not a condition of purchase‚Äù, which is required for the US TCPA (Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991) but not relevant to file in Australia 
- the boilerplate spells ‚Äúauthorize‚Äù with a zed 

I‚Äôve added appropriate eye-roll and ‚Äúzany face‚Äù emoji next to the most ridiculous parts of the text üíÅ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
